newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks seen higher after CPI data.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks seen higher after CPI data.

text.p: U.S. stocks were seen rising on Tuesday after the release of a December report on the consumer price index and retail sales, analysts said.

"The CPI core was below expectations. The Street was using up 0.2 (excluding food and energy), and it came up 0.1 (percent)," said Larry Wachtel, analyst at Prudential Securities. "Everybody uses the core, so the inflation number (is the reason why) bonds are responding."
U.S. consumer prices in December edged higher as inflation for all of 1996 rose at the fastest rate in six years, the Labor Department said.

The Department said the consumer price index rose 0.3 percent in December, identical with November's rise. However, with the often-volatile food and energy sector removed, the so-called core rate increased more modestly, rising only 0.1 percent after being up 0.2 percent in November.
Christmas shopping boosted sales at retail stores modestly during December, the Commerce Department said, as business picked up at clothing and general merchandise stores.

Total retail sales increased last month by 0.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted $208.2 billion after a revised 0.2 percent decline in November. That was slightly stronger than the 0.5 percent sales gain forecast by Wall Street economists.
